conversation.content: Hello doctor, I have abdominal pain and bloating, and I keep vomiting repeatedly.
How long have your symptoms lasted? Where is the pain mainly located? Does the pain change after eating or having a bowel movement?

The symptoms have lasted for 4 days. The pain is mainly in the upper abdomen and radiates to the lower back. It is continuous without obvious relief. Eating does not significantly change the pain, and I haven’t had a bowel movement for several days.
Have you had fever or jaundice?
Yes, I’ve had a fever, with the highest temperature reaching 38.5°C, and my skin and eyes have turned yellow.
What are the results of your complete blood count (CBC) and hepatobiliary–pancreatic biochemical tests? Also, have you had a contrast-enhanced abdominal CT (CECT)?

The CBC shows an elevated white blood cell count of 16.49×10⁹/L, with neutrophils at 89.1%. In the hepatobiliary–pancreatic panel: total bilirubin 123.1 μmol/L, direct bilirubin 99.0 μmol/L, ALT 609 U/L, AST 308 U/L, ALP 245 U/L, GGT 1057 U/L, blood glucose 13.86 mmol/L, triglycerides 6.25 mmol/L.

The contrast-enhanced abdominal CT shows necrotizing pancreatitis, gallstones, and bilateral pleural effusion.
Do you currently have hypotension, shortness of breath, or decreased urine output?
At present, there is no hypotension, shortness of breath, or oliguria.
Have you undergone emergency ERCP for biliary imaging with stone extraction or drainage? Also, have you had an arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis?

Arterial blood gas analysis results: pH 7.35, PaO₂ 75 mmHg, PaCO₂ 35 mmHg, HCO₃⁻ 22 mmol/L, BE −3.5 mmol/L.

ERCP showed an impacted stone at the distal common bile duct. Stone extraction was performed and a nasobiliary drainage tube was placed.

Diagnosis:
1. Conclusion: Acute necrotizing pancreatitis (biliary origin, severe)
   Reasoning: CT demonstrates necrotizing pancreatitis with bilateral pleural effusion; typical severe epigastric pain radiating to the back for 4 days, accompanied by vomiting and ileus (no bowel movement for 4 days)
   Marked inflammatory response: WBC 16.5 ×10⁹/L, neutrophils 89%; fever 38.5°C
   Impacted common bile duct stone confirmed and removed by ERCP, indicating biliary etiology; significant elevation of bilirubin, transaminases, γ-glutamyl transferase (GGT), and alkaline phosphatase (ALP)
   ACG 2024 guidelines classify acute pancreatitis with biliary obstruction or imaging evidence of necrosis as severe

2. Conclusion: Acute obstructive suppurative cholangitis (gallstone-related cholangitis, TG18 Grade III)
   Reasoning: Charcot’s triad (abdominal pain–fever–jaundice) plus elevated cholestatic laboratory markers
   TG18 emphasizes urgent biliary decompression in severe cholangitis; ERCP with stone removal and drainage has been completed

3. Conclusion: Hypertriglyceridemia (6.25 mmol/L) with stress-induced hyperglycemia (13.9 mmol/L)
   Reasoning: Triglycerides > 5.6 mmol/L and glucose > 11 mmol/L, associated with pancreatitis; concurrent metabolic management required

4. Conclusion: Type 2 diabetes mellitus to be ruled out
   Reasoning: First detection of hyperglycemia during the disease course; follow-up evaluation with oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) and/or HbA1c needed
Treatment:
1. Initial supportive care
• Resuscitation: Lactated Ringer’s solution 5–10 mL/kg·h during the first 24 h, target urine output ≥ 0.5 mL/kg·h; close assessment with inferior vena cava (IVC) ultrasound and hematocrit (Hct)
• Analgesia: Intravenous tramadol or oxycodone via continuous infusion; patient-controlled intravenous analgesia (PCIA) if necessary
• Fasting (NPO) ≤ 24 h, then early nasojejunal feeding, 25 kcal/kg/day

2. Control of biliary infection
• Antibiotics: Ertapenem 1 g qd or piperacillin–tazobactam 4.5 g q8h, duration 7–10 days
• ERCP has relieved the obstruction; recheck bilirubin and C-reactive protein (CRP) at 48 h to assess response

3. Monitoring pancreatic necrosis and prevention of complications
• No routine prophylactic antibiotics
• Repeat contrast-enhanced CT at day 7–10: if infected necrosis suspected (gas on imaging, persistent fever) → percutaneous/endoscopic drainage ± step-up antibiotics
• Low-molecular-weight heparin 4000 IU qd for venous thromboembolism (VTE) prophylaxis; bilateral pleural effusion < 30 mm → observation, > 30 mm or with respiratory distress → thoracentesis or tube drainage

4. Metabolic correction
• Continuous intravenous insulin infusion: targets triglycerides < 5.6 mmol/L and glucose 7–10 mmol/L; daily monitoring of triglycerides, glucose, and electrolytes
• Consider single-session plasma exchange if triglycerides ≥ 11.3 mmol/L or metabolic acidosis occurs; current levels do not require this

5. Surgery and follow-up
• After stabilization (normalization of inflammatory markers, anesthesia tolerance), laparoscopic cholecystectomy within 4–6 weeks to prevent recurrent biliary pancreatitis

6. ICU/ward dynamic assessment
• Record respiratory, circulatory, and renal function every 12 h; BISAP score daily
• CRP, procalcitonin (PCT), hematocrit (Hct), liver and renal function every other day; escalate monitoring promptly if SOFA score ≥ 2

7. Discharge and follow-up
• Recheck triglycerides, HbA1c, and abdominal ultrasound 1 month after discharge; complete cholecystectomy within 6 months
• Dietitian-guided low-fat diet (< 15% of total calories), alcohol abstinence, target BMI 18.5–23
